author: owleksiyowpckcr
content: dumb question: what's the reason the gas is charged for code execution? I get the reason to charge gas for accessing state, but why charge for instructions executed? CPU/memory cost of actually executing transactions has to be negligible compared to PoW, and we only do <20 TPS

author: sky.cactus
content: PoW only has to be generated by one person in the world per block, and it can be parallelized very easily.  Block execution has to be done by *everyone* who runs an Ethereum client (which ideally would be everyone who uses Ethereum).

author: owleksiyowpckcr
content:
fair point, but with so few TPS (and no plans to really increase TPS per node) CPU/memory/stack-only operations don't seem to be a big deal. full nodes already require substantial amount of CPU/memory, and it is most likely already dominated by internal node state management

I guess another argument would be that we still want to cap the run time of each transaction, and charging gas per instruction executed makes sense. this brings another question: why different non-state-management instructions have different costs. (and another question is: is there **another** way of capping the run time? perhaps not)

author: sky.cactus
content: We have to consider user experience as well.  In a perfect world, we would have separate costs for network utilization, CPU usage, and storage.  However, users struggle enough already with a single fee type, adding 2 more will make it incredibly difficult for users to understand.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe if EIP-1559 goes over well we can make it so storage is fully charged with a basefee like mechanic, and leave network, CPU, and disk access bundled (since they are things that impact miner profitability).

author: owleksiyowpckcr
content: that's precisely my argument: why not roll all non-storage related opcodes into a single category and give all of them a fixed price (maybe even 0, but that will need another change)? as of now, I see all non-storage related opcodes having **different** gas gost

author: sky.cactus
content: And perhaps if some sort of stateless transactions are introduced we can further adjust.

author: sky.cactus
content: Their cost is very much not 0.  If the cost of any operation is 0, I can take down the network.

author: sky.cactus
content: The way to think about all such problems is to ask yourself, "how could I attack the network if X changed".

author: sky.cactus
content: Or in some cases, "how can I attack the network right now" (like in the pre-Berlin situation).

author: sky.cactus
content: Every change to Ethereum has to take that line of questioning very seriously.  It is trivial to build a system that isn't resilient to attack.  Building it so it is resilient to motivated and well funded attackers is the really hard part.

author: pipermerriam
content: This question is also testable. You could go fork a client and modify the evm gas rules....

author: pipermerriam
content:
That's my interpretation as well. Two is going to be the default. I'm hesitant to do solo because being "alone" on a problem sucks. I'm hesitant to do more than two because I want to keep things simple and have easy 1:1 peer accountability.

author: pipermerriam
content: Yes, assuming things go well, the goal is to evolve this into a rolling thing where new cohorts start while previous cohorts are still active. Each cohort improves the documentation and onboarding material. Goal is to build a smooth on ramp for learning about and contributing to the protocol. Applicants from previous cohorts will be considered for future cohorts so everyone here who has applied  will be in the pool of candidates for the second cohort (cohort-one).

author: timbeiko
content:
This is great, thanks for sharing! <@456226577798135808> under "Benefits", you are missing a few:
1. Have an up-to-date, canonical specification for the Ethereum protocol. The Yellowpaper lags behind the most recent hard forks, so the "spec" today is "YP + EIPs from hard forks not yet included in YP"
2. Post-merge (or when the merge is being spec'ed) having a harmonized Ethereum spec (eth2.0-specs + this new eth1 spec) would reduce confusion by a lot. 
3. Automatically generate tests from the new eth1 spec. Current tests for Eth1 are here: https://github.com/ethereum/tests/
